problem: When the polynomial $p(x)$ is divided by $x - 1,$ the remainder is 3.  When the polynomial $p(x)$ is divided by $x - 3,$ the remainder is 5.  What is the remainder when the polynomial $p(x)$ is divided by $(x - 1)(x - 3)$?
solution:
By the Remainder Theorem, $p(1) = 3,$ and $p(3) = 5.$

Let $q(x)$ and $ax + b$ be the quotient and remainder, respectively, when the polynomial $p(x)$ is divided by $(x - 1)(x - 3),$ so
\[p(x) = (x - 1)(x - 3) q(x) + ax + b.\]Setting $x = 1,$ we get $p(1) = a + b,$ so $a + b = 3.$  Setting $x = 3,$ we get $p(3) = 3a + b,$ so $3a + b = 5.$  Solving, we find $a = 1$ and $b = 2.$

Therefore, the remainder is $\boxed{x + 2}.$
